g.text: Another important and intensively studied class of soft matter system are colloidal systems,
the unique properties of which, such as tunable photonic bandgap and response to external stimuli,
make them attractive for many applications [
]. X-rays are especially well suited for structural
studies of colloidal systems due to their high penetration length. However, the interpretation of the
scattering data frombulk colloidal crystals possessing various defects is usually challenging. Using
raction, it was demonstrated that AXCCAis capable to detect rotational symmetry in
a local arrangement of colloidal particles even in thick colloidal ﬁlms [
discussed LC systems with the long-range BOorder, in which the anisotropy of the di
can be often easily identiﬁed by the unaided eye, the coherent di
consist of the apparently randomspeckles along the scattering ring. Thus, AXCCA is in many cases a
unique technique which allows one to study the local order in colloids [
raction with a 400 nm beam was combined with AXCCA to study
the structure of a dry colloidal ﬁlmconsisting of spherical silica nanoparticles of 19.3 and 12.2 nmin
diameter. Applying AXCCA to individual di
raction patterns and collecting data at di
positions on the sample, the authors were able to observe changes of the colloidal crystal structure
over the scanned area. In Figure
, the spatially resolved maps of two angular Fourier components,
are the corresponding Fourier components of
the normalized CCF, are shown. The signal at
the scattering fromlarger and smaller particles, respectively. The maps of higher order components
4, 6 show how the BO order changes depending on the local ratio between the number of large
Similar spatially resolved maps were retrieved for the phase
, which can be evaluated as the angular Fourier
cients of the scattering intensity along the
orientation of the colloidal crystal structure with respect to a reference axis. Two maps at di
g,h show the existence of patches of similar orientations within the sample,
which resemble the drying front of silica particle suspensions. An analogous approach which includes
a combination of the focused X-ray beam and AXCCA was used in [
four- and sixfold orientational order in the ﬁlmof self-assembled gold nanoparticles.
